attributes.title: lying and DRM type false memories (DRM Videos)

q1.value: Nothing happened! the mnemonic effects of false denials

q3.value: Victims of abuse do not always disclose their abuse experiences. Instead, they may (falsely) deny that abuse occurred to cope with the trauma they experienced. Victims might also be threatened by the perpetrator not to disclose abuse experiences or decide not to disclose because they feel ashamed (Lyon, 2007; McElvaney, 2015). A growing body of research has shown that the mere act of falsely denying might influence memory and lead to forgetting of the abusive events and the investigations during which the denial took place. This forgetting effect was first found in a study by Vieira and Lane (2013) and later replicated and dubbed the ‘denial-induced forgetting effect’ by Otgaar, Howe, Memon, and Wang (2014). In Vieira and Lane’s (2013) study, participants viewed pictures. Then, they were instructed to tell the truth or lie about several objects, some of which were new, and some were already presented. Two days later, participants received a source memory test. Vieira and Lane (2013) showed that memory was worse for previously presented objects whose presence had been falsely denied. In another study, Otgaar and colleagues (2014) found that participants who had falsely denied details of a witnessed video crime remembered fewer details regarding what they had discussed in the investigative interview in which they had denied the events. Thus, falsely denying that an event took place seems to decrease memory for the remembered event and the investigation, although research findings are not always consistent about both (i.e. while the memory effect for the interview has been replicated with a medium effect size quite consistently since it was first found, memory for the details of the crime or initial stimulus is not always found to be impaired.). The negative impacts of false denials on memory ability are problematic, since they indicate that victims of abuse who falsely deny their abuse might not remember the details of the events or the interview correctly, and may contradict what they said in prior police investigations. Such inconsistencies might lead the police to disregard the witness as unreliable (Brewer, Potter, Fisher, Bond, & Luszcz, 1999; Fischer, Vrij, & Leins, 2013). This can further lead to injustices and could have tremendous emotional effects for the victims. Thus, it is important that we fully understand how false denials may influence the denier’s memory and reliability of their statements. To fully understand the impact that false denials have memory and reliability, both negative and possible positive (mnemonic) effects of false denials need to be investigated. Yet, to date mostly negative mnemonic effects of false denials –being that false denials can negatively impact retention of details of the crime and the investigation - have been studied (see also Otgaar, Howe, Smeets, & Wang, 2016; Otgaar, Romeo, Ramakers, & Howe, 2018). However, false denials might also have protective effects for memory. Lying about your experiences by denying that certain details happened might be ‘better’ for memory retention than not talking about the experiences at all; McWilliams, Goodman, Lyons, Newton, and Avila-Mora (2014) found that while lying (by leaving out details or confabulating details) impaired memory, untruthful rehearsal still resulted in better memory than no rehearsal. Thus, falsely denying abuse might preserve memory better than not talking at all in a first investigative interview. Furthermore, new research points towards potential protective mnemonic effects of false denials; False denials had a protective effect against the formation of false memories in a Deese-Roediger-McDermott (DRM) paradigm in two studies by Otgaar, Howe, Mangiulli, and Bücken (in revision). In both experiments, the initial stimuli were Deese-Roediger-McDermott word lists. These are commonly used to generate false memories. They consist of one critical lure and twelve other words that are semantically linked to the lure. The latter is not presented to participants. After exposure to these word-lists, participants were allocated either to the false denial (where they were instructed to falsely deny in response to each question) or control group. In a later memory task, memory for the denial interview, the DRM lists, and false memory for the critical lures were assessed. The denial-induced forgetting effect was replicated. Also, participants in the false denial group developed significantly fewer false memories for the word lists compared to honest controls. Looking at theories of false memory formation further sheds light on the idea that (false) denials may prevent or reduce the formation of false memories. Associative-activation theory (AAT), for instance, poses that spreading activation through a highly interconnected system of memory nodes in a network leads not only to retrieval of memory but also to the creation of false memory (Howe, Wimmer, Gagnon, & Plumpton, 2009; Roediger Balota, & Watson, 2001). The latter would occur when a memory is retrieved and a related node that is semantically connected but not actually relevant to the retrieved memory is activated. False denial of a memory might lead to inhibitory effects at retrieval (Otgaar, Howe, Mangiulli, & Bücken, in revision). AAT would then predict that such an inhibition of a memory node might prevent the retrieval of semantically related information (such as critical lures). The following implications could be drawn from mnemonic effects of false denials presented above; someone who initially falsely denied abuse might be inconsistent in their accounts since their memory for prior interviews is impaired. However, they might be less likely to have adopted wrong information and formed false memories of the experienced events during the investigation process. This is an important implication, since police often uses suggestive questions by, for instance, asking for whether specific details or events took place that might fit with a schema or script the police has of the type of event that was disclosed by the victim (Goodman-Brown, Edelstein, Goodman, Jones, & Gordon, 2003; Lamb et al., 2002). Such questioning may lead to the creation of false memories or beliefs about the experienced event(s) when interviewing suspected victims of abuse. According to the results presented above then, false denials might protect the victim from forming these false memories. Thereby, the information regarding the experienced events might be more reliable than one might think in cases in which the victim initially denied that certain events occurred to them. This is in line with the finding that false denials sometimes only reduce memory for the denial interview, but not for the experienced event (e.g. Otgaar, Howe, Memon, & Wang, 2014). The problem with inferring and generalizing from the research presented above is twofold. First, the positive mnemonic effect of false denials on false memory formation has only been shown in two studies thus far, and thus requires further replication across different studies and paradigms. This is of high importance, especially looking at the replication crisis that the field of psychology is faced with (Stevens, 2017). Second, the initial stimuli used in the two studies– word lists - are not very ecologically valid. Words are very different from autobiographical memories. To understand the impact of false denials on memory and the reliability of statements given by someone who falsely denied the occurrence of certain events in an investigative interview, it is therefore necessary to replicate the results reported above using more ecologically valid stimuli. Therefore, this study will attempt to replicate the denial-induced-forgetting effect and the inhibition of false memory formation after false denial of events using the same paradigm as the studies presented above by Otgaar, Howe, Mangiulli, and Bücken (in revision), but using DRM videos instead of DRM word lists. Videos are arguably much more similar to autobiographical memories than written words are. Therefore, these stimuli will show greater ecological validity. Moreover, previous studies on the denial-induced forgetting effect have successfully found the effect by using videos as the initial stimuli (see for instance Otgaar, Howe, Smeets, & Wang, 2016). While these were not DRM videos, it is likely that the denial induced forgetting effect can be replicated using such videos. Thereby, the current study will examine both positive and negative effects of false denials on memory and ultimately memory/ testimony reliability after an act of false denial. If replication is possible with DRM videos, future studies might attempt to replicate the effect with even more ecologically valid stimuli to assess the robustness of the effect. To maximize ecological validity the research paradigm could, for instance, utilize a mock-crime and a misinformation paradigm to mimic the investigative process when interviewing alleged victims of abuse; in such interviews, police might provide suggestive (mis)information to learn more about the events that happened and to get the victim to talk about the events (Lamb et al., 2002). Therefore, future studies should look at misinformation paradigms as well. However, it is important to first replicate the results using the same paradigm with more ecologically valid stimuli before other false memory paradigms are tested. Research question: How do false denials of details of DRM videos affect memory and false memory formation of an interview and the originally viewed videos?

q4.value: Hypotheses: 1. Participants will have poorer memory for the interview in which they were asked to falsely deny compared to the interview in which they were being honest - in line with the denial-induced forgetting effect. 2. Participants will create fewer false memories/ endorse less critical lures in the source memory test for the Video/ interview in which they falsely denied compared to the interview in which they were honest. 3. there will be no effect of the order in which participants are asked to falsely deny vs be honest 4. there will be no effect on whether the negative versus neutral video was shown first.

question.value:
mixed design: 

the variable of interest is within participants: the lying condition (false denials vs honest controls). 

Control variables: 
1. order of DRM Videos shown (negative first vs neutral first) 
2. order in which participants are instructed to falsely deny versus respond honestly (false denial firts vs honest Control firtst)

question.value:
Phase 1: video 1 
1.	All participants will be presented with a first DRM video (1 min 30 seconds long).
2.	A short distractor task will be administered.
3.	Then, participants will complete a recognition memory test to assess their baseline memory ability. 
4.	Another short distractor task will be administered. 
5.	After this, participants will engage in a memory interview. In this interview, participants will be randomly allocated to the two experimental groups: the false denial first group, in which they will be instructed to falsely deny having seen certain aspects of the DRM video, or the honest control first group. This interview will include details from the original videos and false details, including all of the critical lures. 
6.	Another short distractor task will be administered
7.	Lastly, participants will undergo a source memory test. This memory test will include elements that were part of the interview (some that were new here and some that were also part of the DRM videos), the critical lures, elements that were only part of the initial video, and some new elements. 
Distractor task between phase 1 and phase 2 
Phase 2: second DRM video and lying/ honest condition
1.	All participants will be presented with a second DRM video (1 min 30 seconds long).
2.	A short distractor task will be administered.
3.	Then, participants will complete a recognition memory test to assess their baseline memory ability. 
4.	Another short distractor task will be administered. 
5.	After this, participants will engage in a memory interview. In this interview, participants who were instructed to falsely deny in the first phase, will be asked to respond honestly. Participants who were asked to be honest in the first phase will be asked to falsely deny having seen aspects in the second video. This interview will include details from the second DRM video and false details, including all of the critical lures for video 2. 
6.	Another short distractor task will be administered
7.	Lastly, participants will undergo a source memory test. This memory test will include elements that were part of the interview (some that were new here and some that were also part of the DRM videos), the critical lures, elements that were only part of the second video, and some new elements.

q13.value:
Using G*Power, I ran an a priori power analysis (t-test; matched pairs) with an anticipated medium effect size (dz=0.5) based on prior research on false denials and a power of 0.8. This power analysis showed that a sample of 34 participants, is needed. 

my sample size is the number of participants who engage in the proposed Experiment. at least 34 Units will be analysed to meet the Goal to compare between the lying and honest condition (Independent variable of interest)

q14.value: Using G*Power, I ran an a priori power analysis (t-test; matched pairs) with an anticipated medium effect size (dz=0.5) based on prior research on false denials and a power of 0.8. This power analysis showed that a sample of 34 participants, is needed.

question.value:
Within participants:
1.	Lying condition (false denial vs honest control) 	

Control variables: between participants:
2.	Order of the lying condition (false denial first vs honest control first) 
3.	Order of DRM videos (negative vs neutral first)

Dependent Variable(s): - - number of critical lures endorsed in the source memory test - memory score for recognition of true details from the DRM videos (the sum of details correctly identified in the source memory test as having been part of the DRM videos) - memory score for recognition of true details from the interview (the sum of details correctly identified in the source memory test as having been part of the interview) - baseline true memory score (sum of correct details endorsed in the baseline memory test)

A dependent samples t-test will be run on the difference in the means between participants' memory scores (defined as the dependent variables above) in the false denial and honest condition. 

Independent samples t-tests will be used to test whether there are differences in participants' memory scores depending on whether the order in which the Videos were presented and the order in which they were allocated to the lying versus honest condition.

q21.value:
I will use p-values and a cut-off of alpha = 0.05. 
I will be using two-tailed tests.

q22.value: Outliers (> 2 standard deviations) will be excluded from the analysis.

q23.value: incomplete or missing data will lead to the exclusion of the data unit from the final analyses.

q24.value: we might include exploratory analyses on the difference in the effect of lying on memory for emotional versus neutral material (since one DRM video is negative, the other neutral).

attributes.title: Young children’s subjective and objective thresholds of visual consciousness using a backward masking task

q1.value: Young children’s subjective and objective thresholds of visual consciousness using a backward masking task

q3.value:
Understanding consciousness is one of the most important and challenging issues in science. Until now, consciousness studies have studied for adults using psychophysical and neuroscience techniques (e.g., Del Cul et al., 2007; Derda et al., 2019). The visual backward masking task is a widely used measure in consciousness research. Previous studies have shown that the relationship between the subjective visibility and the stimulus intensity (the stimulus presented duration) was fitted a non-linear model (Sandberg et al., 2011; Winder et al., 2013). Furthermore, the threshold of subjective visibility is longer than that of objective performance (Sandberg et al., 2011; Winder et al., 2013).
For a better understanding of consciousness, it is necessary to consider not only adults' developed consciousness but also developing consciousness since human birth. Gelskov and Kouider. (2010) and Kouider et al. (2013) showed that infants’ threshold of the objective performance (the preferential looking) was longer than adults. This suggests that visual consciousness develops even in infants. However, infants could not report subjective visibility. Therefore, the result cannot be compared directly to those of adults. In the current study, we will investigate visual consciousness in young children who can report subjective visibility.
More specifically, we will examine young children's subjective (the visibility rate) and objective (the accuracy rate) thresholds of visual consciousness using a backward masking task. Furthermore, we compare young children's visual consciousness models (Sandberg et al., 2011) with adults' ones.

q4.value:
According to previous research of infants and adults (Gelskov and Kouider, 2010; Kouider et al., 2013; Sandberg et al., 2011; Winder et al., 2013), we have four hypotheses.
1) Young children’s subjective threshold is longer than the objective one.
2) Young children’s subjective model is more graded than the objective one.
3) Young children’s subjective and objective thresholds are longer than adults’ ones.
4) Young children’s subjective and objective models are more graded than adults’ ones.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
We have one within-participant factor, SOA (20, 40, 60, 80, 100, 160, 200, 260 ms), and one between-participant factor, age group (young children and adults).
We have two dependent factors, accuracy and visibility.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Adults participants will be recruited through advertisements on the bulletin board in the university or in the psychology lectures. They will be paid 500 JPY for their participation at the end of the experiment.  Participants must be at least 20 years old.
Young Children participants will be recruited from the baby and young children researchers pool of the university. Their parents will be paid 2000 JPY for their and their parents' participation at the end of the experiment. Young children participants' age will be ranged from four to six.

q13.value: Our target sample size for the analysis is 40 participants (20 participants for young children and adults, respectively).

q14.value: We decided the sample size according to previous research. The typical sample size for a visual awareness task is about 20 (e.g., Del Cul et al., 2007; Windey et al., 2013).

question.value:
We will manipulate the target-mask stimulus onset asynchrony (SOA). The eight levels of SOA are 20, 40, 60, 80, 100, 160, 200, and 260 ms. 
We will have two age group. The one is young children group, and another one is adults group.
We will measure the accuracy and visibility of the visual awareness task.

We will fit the accuracy and visibility data to four-parameter non-linear models (Sandberg et al., 2011).
𝑓(𝑥)=𝑎 + (𝑏−𝑎)/(1+exp((𝑐−𝑥)/𝑑)) 
The parameters a and b reflect the lower and upper boundary. Therefore, a = 0, b = 1 in the accuracy and a = 1, b = 4 in the Visibility. Parameters c and d reflect the index point and the steepness of the curve. The parameter c denotes the centre of the slope, and the parameter d is a measure of the steepness of the slope. Higher parameter d means that the model is more graded.

For analyzing young children's subjective and objective thresholds of visual consciousness, we will use binomial tests to judge that the accuracy rate and visibility rate are above or near chance (50%) at each SOA. We also will use a one-way ANOVA. The independent variables are SOAs and the dependent variables are the accuracy rate and visibility rate. Moreover, we will fit the subjective visibility rate and the accuracy rate to non-linear models (subjective model and objective model).
For comparing young children's visual consciousness models compared with adults' ones, we will use a two-way ANOVA. The independent variables are models (subjective vs. objective) and age groups (young children vs. adults) and the dependent variables are the parameter c and d.

registration_responses.q1: Young children’s subjective and objective thresholds of visual consciousness using a backward masking task
registration_responses.q3:
Understanding consciousness is one of the most important and challenging issues in science. Until now, consciousness studies have studied for adults using psychophysical and neuroscience techniques (e.g., Del Cul et al., 2007; Derda et al., 2019). The visual backward masking task is a widely used measure in consciousness research. Previous studies have shown that the relationship between the subjective visibility and the stimulus intensity (the stimulus presented duration) was fitted a non-linear model (Sandberg et al., 2011; Winder et al., 2013). Furthermore, the threshold of subjective visibility is longer than that of objective performance (Sandberg et al., 2011; Winder et al., 2013).
For a better understanding of consciousness, it is necessary to consider not only adults' developed consciousness but also developing consciousness since human birth. Gelskov and Kouider. (2010) and Kouider et al. (2013) showed that infants’ threshold of the objective performance (the preferential looking) was longer than adults. This suggests that visual consciousness develops even in infants. However, infants could not report subjective visibility. Therefore, the result cannot be compared directly to those of adults. In the current study, we will investigate visual consciousness in young children who can report subjective visibility.
More specifically, we will examine young children's subjective (the visibility rate) and objective (the accuracy rate) thresholds of visual consciousness using a backward masking task. Furthermore, we compare young children's visual consciousness models (Sandberg et al., 2011) with adults' ones.
registration_responses.q4:
According to previous research of infants and adults (Gelskov and Kouider, 2010; Kouider et al., 2013; Sandberg et al., 2011; Winder et al., 2013), we have four hypotheses.
1) Young children’s subjective threshold is longer than the objective one.
2) Young children’s subjective model is more graded than the objective one.
3) Young children’s subjective and objective thresholds are longer than adults’ ones.
4) Young children’s subjective and objective models are more graded than adults’ ones.

We will manipulate the target-mask stimulus onset asynchrony (SOA). The eight levels of SOA are 20, 40, 60, 80, 100, 160, 200, and 260 ms.

registration_responses.q17.question: We will measure the accuracy and visibility of the visual awareness task.
registration_responses.q18.question:
We will fit the accuracy and visibility data to four-parameter non-linear models (Sandberg et al., 2011).
𝑓(𝑥)=𝑎 + (𝑏−𝑎)/(1+exp((𝑐−𝑥)/𝑑)) 
The parameters a and b reflect the lower and upper boundary. Therefore, a = 0, b = 1 in the accuracy and a = 1, b = 4 in the Visibility. Parameters c and d reflect the index point and the steepness of the curve. The parameter c denotes the centre of the slope, and the parameter d is a measure of the steepness of the slope. Higher parameter d means that the model is more graded.

Moreover, we will fit the subjective visibility rate and the accuracy rate to non-linear models (subjective model and objective model).
For comparing young children's visual consciousness models compared with adults' ones, we will use a two-way ANOVA. The independent variables are models (subjective vs. objective) and age groups (young children vs. adults) and the dependent variables are the parameter c and d.

attributes.title: Emoji and perception of author identity

q1.value: Emoji and perception of author identity

q2.value: Alexander Robertson, Sharon Goldwater, Walid Magdy

q3.value:
Our prior work has shown that Twitter users produce skin-toned emoji, as part of their social media posts, which very closely match their actual real life skin tone.

This leaves open questions about whether viewers of these social media posts use their observation of skin-toned emoji to come to a conclusion about the author's identity.

Therefore, we will measure how participants react to social media posts containing emoji of different skin tones, in terms of judgements they make about the author of the text. We will use a matched guise test to do this: participants are shown social media posts with no emoji, yellow emoji, black emoji or white emoji. They are then asked to decide whether the post was written by a black or a white author.

Of course, text itself can give linguistic clues regarding author identity. If a text is strongly associated with black/white speakers, then this may override any attached emoji. We therefore pre-norm texts and group them according to black, neutral and white. 

As a baseline, the neutral tweets with no emoji should be judged at random, with equal number of judgements for black/white.

If participants link emoji skin tones to human identity, neutral tweets containing a black/white emoji should more often be judged to have an author with a matching skin tone.

The yellow emoji is considered by some to be a neutral representation of human skin colour. If this claim holds, then judgements of neutral text with a yellow emoji should be similar to neutral text without emoji.

Our prior work also showed that people of colour (POC) are more likely to use skin-toned emoji and also use them more often. Therefore, this population may be more willing to connect emoji with identity due to their experience of doing so in practice. We predict that people of colour, when presented with a text containing an emoji, will be more likely than non-POC participants to select an option that matches the emoji tone. 

Finally, there is the question of how people will resolve conflict in identity signals, such as a text with a Black linguistic bias but a white emoji attached. We intend to explore this situation, in order to derive research questions for future possible work.

q4.value:
Our baseline results (B1.1, B1.2) are motivated by the findings from our own norming study, where we gauged how participants react to the absence/presence of linguistic identity signals within a text. We expect to replicate the findings, which were that some texts are consistently considered to have black or white authorship, while other texts are considered neutral because neither black nor white authorship is chosen consistently by participants.

B1.1: Neither Black or White readers of neutral texts (that contain no emoji) will strongly identify these texts with any particular author identity.

	A neutral text is one with no indicators of the author's ethnic identity. Such indicators are generally linguistic, expressed through syntactic patterns or lexical content. The absence of these indicators has been confirmed through pre-testing of the texts in a norming study.

B1.2: Both Black and White readers of biased text (which contain no emoji) will identify these more strongly and consistently than neutral texts with a particular author ethnicity, aligning with the bias of the text.

	A biased text is one that does have indicators of the author's ethnic identity. The presence of these indicators (but not specific identification of them, e.g. syntactic or lexical features) has been confirmed through pre-testing of the texts in a norming study.


Our hypotheses  (H1, H2) are motivated by findings of previous work claiming a connection between emoji and expression of identity, and by popular claims made in the media (H3).

H1: Readers of a neutral text containing a light- or dark-skinned emoji will be more likely to attribute authorship to someone whose skin tone matches that of the emoji.
	H1 is motivated by findings in sociolinguistics, that people use multiple cues to reach conclusions about a person's identity. Testing this hypothesis will tell us whether emoji are in fact such a cue. 

H2: Readers with darker skin will be more likely than lighter-skinned readers to attribute authorship to someone whose skin tone matches that of the emoji, given a neutral text.

	H2 is motivated by findings in previous studies, that people of colour produce more skin-toned emoji in their social media messages. We expect that greater experience of expressing identity through emoji will make such users more attuned to perceiving such emoji use by others as an explicit act of self-representation.

H3: Black readers will be more likely to attribute the default yellow emoji to a White than a Black identity, given a neutral text.

	There have been untested claims in the media that the yellow emoji is neutral, with regards to skin colour identity, and therefore represents everyone. This claim has been used to support arguments that the addition of skin-toned emoji to the Unicode Standard was unnecessary. However, our own previous work has shown that Black users are more likely to have used skin-toned emoji than White users, suggesting that yellow may not in fact be perceived as neutral. H3 tests that hypothesis. White users, who we found are less likely to have used skin-toned emoji, may therefore see Yellow as either Neutral or White. White readers in our experiment should therefore also select White more often than Black, but perhaps to a lesser extent than Black readers.

Alongside our hypotheses, we have open-ended research questions where we are unable to make any principled predictions. Specifically, how does the linguistic content of text interact with emoji? If a text by itself is already perceived as being "black" or  "white" due to its stylistic, syntactic, lexical properties, how does this perception change when an emoji is added? The combinations of 

RQ1: What effect is observed when adding a congruent emoji to a text? Do readers perceive it as even more "black'' or "white"? Or is there no effect when compared to just the text alone? And do Black and White reader exhibit any effect to the same degree?

	In RQ1, we expect that the addition of a congruent emoji would have either no effect or a boosting effect. In a no effect outcome, participant judgements will be similar to those for the biased text alone. In a boosting effect outcome, the rating of the biased text will be even more in favour of the particular bias.

RQ2: What effect is observed when adding an incongruent emoji to a text, creating a signal conflict? Do readers use the text or the emoji to come to a conclusion? Or is there confusion?

	In RQ2, participants must resolve a conflict between the signals given by the text and the emoji, such as a text with a Black linguistic bias containing a white emoji or vice versa. If participants rate these stimuli as 50:50, this suggests there is an unresolved confusion about which signal to use - some participants will use the text to decide, some the emoji, others will guess at random. If the ratio is in favour of the identity reflected by either text or emoji, this suggests that one signal dominates and is used to resolve the conflict.

RQ3: How do individual differences in linguistic/emoji knowledge affect how signal conflict is resolved?

	We might expect individual differences to come into play here, as participants may not be equally familiar with the linguistic characteristics of "black" or "white" text -- particularly "black" text, which is less standard and therefore fewer White participants are exposed to it regularly. Similarly, Black participants may be more familiar with self-representational usage of emoji because of their popularity among Black Twitter users (as per our previous work). Therefore, Black users may be more willing to ignore the text signal in favour of the emoji signal.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
We have a 2 group within-subjects design.

We have 2 factors, with 3 and 4 levels each.

Group 1: Black participants
Group 2: White participants

Factor A : emoji present : none, yellow, black, white
Factor B : text bias : black, neutral, white

q9.value:
We will use block randomisation. Each participant will be assigned at random to an equally sized predetermined block.

These blocks determine which emoji factor is applied to which text stimulus, in order to ensure each participant sees each text only once.

The order of presentation of the trials is also randomised.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value:
Existing data: texts normed for perception of author identity

We have a dataset of annotated tweets from a previous study. These tweets are annotated with the ethnicity of the author, sampled from tweets made in 2017, by users based in London.

From these we selected 100 random tweets ending with an emoji that can have a skin tone applied: 50 by Black authors, 50 by White.

We resampled until these tweets contained no profanity, sensitive topics or personal information, while preserving the ratio of Black:White authors.

These tweets (with the emoji removed) were then judged in a forced match setup, to determine the extent to which the text alone is informative about author identity.

40 participants (20 Black, 20 White) were recruited through the Prolific.ac platform, which allows filtering by demographics. Each participant rated all 100 texts as having Black or White authorship.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 488, with 244 participants in each group. The Prolific.ac platform makes it easy to replace participants who drop out or do not complete the experiment.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .90 power to detect a medium effect size of .15 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

question.value:
We manipulate the informativity of the text stimuli, in terms of associated it is with Black/White authors. The three levels of this categorical variable are Black, Neutral, White.

We further manipulate the emoji content that appears along with the text. The four levels of this categorical variable are No Emoji, Yellow Emoji, Black Emoji, White Emoji.
The single outcome variable will be the judgements of stimuli. Participants will judge them as having either a Black or a White author.

Our comparative analyses rely on measuring the ratio of Black:White judgements made by participants, in response to stimuli where the text bias is either Black/Neutral/White and there is also either None/Yellow/Black/White emoji present. 

B1.1: Measure ratio of Black:White judgements for Neutral texts with no emoji attached. Prediction: ratios should be approximately 50% and act as the reference point for further experiments.

B1.2: Measure ratio of Black:White judgements for Black/White biased texts with no emoji attached. Prediction: ratios should be more in favour of the particular bias of the text. Using Fisher's Exact Test, there should be a significant difference between the ratios here and the neutral texts seen in B1.1.

H1: Measure ratio of Black:White judgements for Neutral texts with a Black or White emoji attached. Prediction: ratios should be more in favour of the colour of the emoji. Using Fisher's Exact Test, there should be a significant difference between the ratios here and those seen in B1.1.

H2: Measure ratio of Black:White judgements for Neutral texts with a Black or White emoji. Prediction: Black participants will more often make a judgement matching the emoji colour. Using Fisher's Exact test, there should be a significant difference between the ratios here for the Black participant group compared to the White participant group.

H3: Measure ratio of Black:White judgements for Neutral texts with a Yellow emoji, for Black and White participants. Prediction: Black readers will be more likely to attribute the default yellow emoji to a White than a Black identity, given a neutral text. Using Fisher's Exact test, there should be a significant difference between the ratios here for the Black participant group compared to their baseline result of B1.1. The White participant group should show no significant difference to their baseline result of B1.1.

RQ1: For Black and White participants, measure the ratio of Black:White judgements for Black text with Black emoji/White text with White emoji. Possible outcome: boosting effect of emoji. Using Fisher's Exact Test, if there is a significant difference between the ratios here and those in B1.2, and the ratios here are more in favour of the attached emoji, then this would be evidence in support of the existence of a boosting effect.

RQ2:  For Black and White participants, measure ratio of Black:White judgements for Black text with White emoji/White text with Black emoji. Possible outcomes: unresolved confusion or dominance of either text/emoji. Using Fisher's Exact Test, if there is no significant difference between the result here and that of B1.2, then this would be evidence in support of unresolved confusion. If there is a significant difference, then this would be evidence in support of dominance. Determining the dominant factor can be done by examining whether the largest proportion of judgements goes toward the identity matching the text or the emoji.

RQ3: As above, but rather than comparing each participant group to their baseline from B1.2, compare across participant groups using Fisher's Exact Text.

q21.value: We will use the standard p greater than .05 criteria for determining if the Fisher's Exact Test  suggest there is a difference in ratios for Black/White participants, for Black/Neutral/White texts, for No/Yellow/Black/White emoji.

q22.value:
Users who press the same button (e.g. always left, always right) will be excluded and replaced.

Users who complete the experiment too quickly or too slowly (+/- 2 standard deviations from the mean completion time) will be excluded.

If there is a significant difference, then this would be evidence in support of dominance. Determining the dominant factor can be done by examining whether the largest proportion of judgements goes toward the identity matching the text or the emoji.

RQ3: As above, but rather than comparing each participant group to their baseline from B1.2, compare across participant groups using Fisher's Exact Text.

attributes.title: Perception of rape- interaction of origin and socioeconomic status of the perpetrator
attributes.description: We are going to find out whether the interaction of origin and socioeconomic status of the rape perpetrator influences the level of victim blaming, perceived perpetrator's blame, perceived victim's credibility and perceived trauma. We are going also to include the victim-perpetrator relationship as well as the level of right-wing authoritarianism, social dominance orientation and system justification

q1.value: The role of the victim-perpetrator relationship, the origins and the socioeconomic status of the perpetrator in the rape victim blaming

q3.value: According to dual-process model of prejudice by Duckitt, right-wing authoritarianism (RWA) and social dominance orientation (SDO) both predict prejudice, nevertheless, there are different mechanisms underlying it. RWA is based on perceiving the world as dangerous and SDO- on perceiving the world as a competitive jungle. In our study we would like to find out what is the better predictor of victim blaming- RWA or SDO and whether it depends on the circumstances of rape- victim-perpetrator relationship, origin of the perpetrator and socioeconomic status of the perpetrator.

q4.value:
1. In the case of an acquaintance rape the level of perceived victim’s blame (VB) will be higher than in the case of a stranger rape.
2. In the case of an acquaintance rape the level of perceived perpetrator’s blame (PB), perceived credibility of the victim (PC), perceived trauma of the victim (PT) and proposed sentence for the perpetrator will be lower than in the case of a stranger rape.
3.  In the case of a rape committed by an in-group member the level of VB will be higher when the perpetrator will have a high socioeconomic status (vs. low socioeconomic status). 
4. In the case of a rape committed by an in-group member the level of PB, PC, PT and proposed sentence for the perpetrator will be lower when the perpetrator will have a high socioeconomic status (vs. low socioeconomic status). 
5. In the case of a stranger rape the level of VB will be higher when the perpetrator will be an in-group member (vs. out-group member).
6. In the case of a stranger rape the level of PB, PC, PT and proposed sentence for the perpetrator will be lower when the perpetrator will be an in-group member (vs. out-group member).
7. In the case of an acquaintance rape the level of VB will be higher when the perpetrator will be an out-group member (vs. in-group member).
8. In the case of an acquaintance rape the level of PC will be lower when the perpetrator will be an out-group member (vs. in-group member).
9. In the case of an acquaintance rape the level of PB, PT and proposed sentence for the perpetrator will be lower when the perpetrator will be an in-group member (vs. out-group member).
10. The level of VB in the case of high socioeconomic status of the perpetrator will be predicted by SDO and system justification.
11. The level of VB in the case of the in-group membership of the perpetrator will be predicted by RWA.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study will be conducted in a within-between subject design. The rape vignettes will include three variables: socioeconomic status of the rape perpetrator (high vs. low), the origin of the perpetrator (in-group member vs out-group member) and the relationship between the perpetrator and the victim (stranger rape vs acquaintance rape). Every participant will read two rape cases differing in these variables. The versions of the experiment and the order of the vignettes will be randomized in Qualtrics.

q9.value: We are going to apply the second-level randomization- the versions of the experiment will be chosen randomly in Qualtrics.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We are going to conduct the study among Polish people, mostly students. We will recruit them through the research panel Answeo. They will obtain a small remuneration (approx. 1.25 USD).

q14.value: We assume that the effect size f = .15 will be significant and we expect the power to be .95. We need N = 75 in order to conduct a multiple regression with 6 predictors. We intend to recruit 100 persons in case of need of excluding some data e.g. because of too short completion time.

question.value:
-socioeconomic status of the rape perpetrator (high vs. low )
-origin of the perpetrator (in-group member vs out-group member)
-relationship between the perpetrator and the victim (stranger rape vs acquaintance rape)

-victim blaming, perpetrator blaming, perceived trauma and perceived credibility: the participants read the vignettes concerning rape and answer a short survey concerning the attribution of blame to the victim and to the perpetrator, the perceived trauma and the perceived credibility of the victim; each participant will obtain two versions of the vignette: with a stranger rape and an acquaintance rape
-proposed punishment for the rape perpetrator described in each vignette (2-12 years, according to Polish Penal Code)

-right-wing authoritarianism (RWA): an attitude which consists of three aspects: submissiveness toward the authorities, aggression toward minorities and a strong attachment to conventions and rules
-gender
-age
-educational attainment
-mood

In order to test the H3-H9 we are going to use the ANOVA.
In order to test the H10 and H11 we are going to use the multiple regression model.

q21.value: The acceptable level of significance is p<.05.

q1.value: Influencing cognitive immunization of social expectations: A comparation of interventions targeting expectations and psychological flexibility.

q2.value: Anne-Catherine Ewen, Winfried Rief, Marcel Wilhelm

q3.value:
Research focusing on expectations, defined as a part of cognitions, seems to be a promising approach differentiating people with a mental illness and people mentally healthy. Rief and Joormann (2019) established a new cognitive model including expectations as a core part of depression. Accordingly, to change one’s negative expectations, they must be violated, i.e. by positive experiences. However, these negative expectations seem to persist, even after an expectation violation. This lack of adjustment might be due to cognitive immunization, defined as post hoc reappraisal of positive experiences (Rief & Glombiewski, 2016). Based on this theoretical background, cognitive behavioral therapy should include the work on dysfunctional expectations (expectation focused psychological interventions, EFPI) to stimulate the flexible and functional adaptation of expectations to experienced situations (e.g. Rief & Glombiewski, 2016; Doering, Glombiewski & Rief, 2018). 

Another concept focusing on psychological flexibility is Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT). As a part of the third wave of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), ACT tries to enhance the cognitive flexibility by stimulating the acceptance of the present moment with the aim of reducing experiential avoidance and promoting committed action towards proper values in life (Hayes, Strosahl & Wilson, 2016). In contrast to EFPI, which is a totally new approach and efficacy studies are still lacking, ACT is already well established in practice, even if further methodologically high quality randomized clinical trials are needed to state it as an evidence-based treatment (Öst, 2014). 

The two approaches seem to have some common points, for instance the importance of the flexible use of cognition and expectations. The questions arise: Do short interventions of EFPI and psychological flexibility focused interventions (PFFI; derived from ACT) enhance behavioral change and if yes, do they differ regarding their mechanisms? The aim of this study is to analyze the influence of these therapeutic concepts on behavior (measured in this study with the help of the prisoner´s dilemma). While PFFI should reduce the link between expectations and consequent behavior by enhancing committed action towards values independently of negative expectations, EFPI is expected to decrease cognitive immunization by making expectations and their violations conscious, giving the opportunity to flexibly adapt expectations and their consequent behavior.

q4.value:
1. Both groups EFPI and PFFI will differ significantly in behavior during the repeated prisoner´s dilemma (in number/ percentage and variability of cooperation or defection) compared to the control group (distraction). 

2. EFPI will lead to a faster adaptation of expectations compared to the PFFI group and an active control group (distraction) entailing a faster behavioral change from defection to cooperation in the repeated prisoner´s dilemma, when the negative expectation is violated through the sudden cooperation of the “other person”. In all, a higher level of cooperation compared to the control group will be assumed.

3. PFFI will lead to a higher valued based behavior in the prisoner’s dilemma (regardless of situation specific expectations) compared to the EFPI-group or active control group. Participants specifying cooperation (solidarity, generosity, fairness) as a main value, will cooperate more, whereas participants specifying competitiveness (winning, dominance, assertiveness) as a main value, will defect more, compared to the control group. The relation between expectation and behavior during the repeated prisoner´s dilemma will be lower as for the other two groups (acting according to own values, regardless the expectations they have).
  
4. Psychological flexibility will have a moderating effect on behavioral change and expectation adaptation (cooperation instead of defection) in the EFPI group.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: Participants will be blinded towards research-questions.

question.value:
At first, recruited subjects will be randomized into one of three groups (EFPI, PFFI, active control group). At the beginning, subjects are asked to complete baseline questionnaires (see variables for details). After the baseline assessment, the rules of the iterated prisoner´s dilemma (12 trails) will be explained to the subjects. Afterwards, participants will face a video of another person, thinking it is another participant sitting in another experimental room communicating through video call. This video has been constructed to inject negative expectations towards the person on the video, who is acting very uninterested and distant. The participant will be told to explain the rules of the iterated prisoner´s dilemma to the “other” person. Just afterwards, participants will be asked about their actual affect and their global expectation of cooperation of that other person, who they just met through video call. In a next step, the participant will play the prisoner´s dilemma in repeat believing to play with/against the person they just met on the video conference. To enhance the negative social expectations (the other is not trustworthy and will defect all the time), the algorithm of the prisoner`s dilemma will defect 75%, cooperating in the first, fourth and ninth trial only (CDDDCDDDCDDD; Sorgi & van’t Wout, 2016). The gained money in each trial will be shown in a table summing up the earned points for the participant and the “other” person. Moreover, the participant will be asked how his expectation of play of the opponent person will be (“On a scale from 0 to 100%, how likely do you think the other person will cooperate?”). After the game, participants will again be asked about their actual affective state, their happiness of their earned points and importance of winning, their actual estimate of trustworthiness of the other person, their state of psychological flexibility (PsyFlex, Firsching et al., validation study in submission) and their belief being able to influence the behavior of the other (locus of control).  

Subsequently, participants will receive an intervention, depending on the group they were randomized to. In the EFPI-group participants will be taught about expectations, their influence on their behavior, and their mechanisms of adaptation including immunization. The PFFI-group will consist of interactive work on values, committed action, and defusion with the use of some ACT interventions. Fusion, Evaluation, Avoidance, and reason-giving will be contrasted to accept, choose, and take action. At last, the active control group consists of the explanation of different models of attention and an interactive exercise named “look-point-name” as a distraction task. 

In a third part, social negative expectations will be violated. Again, participants will meet the “other” person per video call and this time the person on the video will be attentive, friendly and interested. Participants shall explain the interventions they received. Further on the affective state will be asked as well as the global trustworthiness and the expectation of the ability to cooperate of the other person.  The prisoner´s dilemma will be played for a second time, the “other” person will now cooperate 75% (DCCCDCCCDCCC) suggesting an expectation violation. Again, the expectation of cooperation or defection of the “other person” will be asked before every trial. At the end, participants are asked to rate their actual affective state, their happiness of their earned points, importance of winning, their actual estimate of trustworthiness of the other person, their state of psychological flexibility and their belief being able to influence the behavior of the other. 

At the end, a follow-up questionnaire will check the validity of the study and the emotional state of the participants to ensure no enduring negative impact of the negative expectation induction. In a last step, participants will be enlightened about the illusion of talking and playing against a real person.

q9.value: A block randomization will be used, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the three equally sized intervention groups. The random number list will be created using the statistical program R.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Healthy participants will be recruited via flyers distributed and hang up in public places like supermarkets, cinemas or coffee shops, via local groups on social media platforms like Facebook, via SONA (Research Participation System of the Philipps-University of Marburg), as well as through mailing lists of the Philipps-University of Marburg (students and employees). Subjects will receive 8 Euros per hour of participation. Psychology students can receive subject hours they must collect for their bachelor´s degree. The goal is to recruit 100 participants. Healthy participants must be fluent in German, no other exclusion criteria will be applied.

q13.value: The sample size should at least include 102 participants.

q14.value: A priori power analyses were calculated for ANOVA with repeated measures, within-between factors with a moderate effect (f=0.25).  Literature is suggesting a medium effect size of the acceptance and commitment therapy, comparable to other established treatments (e.g. Powers, M.B., Zum Vörde Sive Vörding, M.B. & Emmelkamp, P.M.G., 2009; A-Tjak, J.G.L., Davis, M.L., Morina, N. Powers, M.B., Smits J.A.J. & Emmelkamp, P.M.G., 2015). Comparing the 12 measurements of the prisoner´s dilemma between the 3 groups, a sample size of 24 is needed (Power 0.95, α=0.05). Comparing the change of the behavior between the 3 groups using summary statistics (e.g. variance, number of cooperation…), a sample size of 66 is needed (Power 0.95, α=0.05).  Further on, the paper of Sorgi and van´t Wout (2016) on which we orientated our analyses included 31 participants involved in all 3 groups (31 participants per group, without a cross-over design N=92).

question.value:
Participants will be randomized into one of three groups: EFPI, FPI and an active control group. The planned content will be described in the following section. 

The expectation focused psychology intervention (EFPI) focuses on making the participant more attentive to expectation violations in order to reduce cognitive immunization and facilitate the integration of positive experiences into positive expectations. At first, a definition of expectations will be discussed with the participant. Dysfunctional (i.e. producing experiential avoidance as a consequence of negative affect) and functional (i.e. planning own behavior to avoid negative consequences) negative expectations will be distinguished, as well as positive and neutral ones. Expectations derive from personality, social surroundings and earlier experiences (Kube et al.,2019). The link between expectations and reactive behavior will be drawn as well as the consequences of it. Different reactions on expectations are explained with focus on immunization. At the end, the whole theoretical background will be elaborated regarding a personal example of the participant (e.g. being afraid of presenting in front of people, being sure to fail in the next exams, expecting my partner to reject me when I say what I want, expecting my partner to reject me, when I am cooperating …). The active and flexible decision of an adaptation of the expectations due to made experiences will be singled out as taking home message. This intervention is hypothesized to make the participant more attentive for expectation violation and thus to a higher adaptation of positive expectations after the positive second interaction. 

In the psychological flexibility focused intervention (PFFI) group, different tasks and metaphors of the acceptance and commitment therapy will be used to promote valued-based behavior and the distance-taking process from cognitions i.e. expectations. Firstly, important values of the participant are singled out with the help of the gravestone metaphor. Values are compared to a compass, giving a direction in life. Secondly, the Bus-driver metaphor will be used to emphasize the influence of daily cognitions due to stress, routine etc. getting the bus off track. This exercise shall include some examples of difficult cognitions of the participant. The image of the monster on the road-side metaphor summarizes the discussion. Fusion, Evaluation, Avoidance and reason-giving is opposed to accept, choose and take action (Wengenroth, 2017). This intervention group should weaken the link between behavior and expectation. The link in the part of positive expectation violation between expectations and actual behavior (i.e. cooperation, defection) will be weaker as in the other groups, respectively in the first prisoner`s dilemma game. Both interventions are comparable in length (+/- 20 minutes), complexity and structure (“psycho-education” or explanation of mechanisms with the help of graphics, personal involvement through the integration and processing of personal examples, take home message).  

The active control group consists of finding a definition of attention with the participant. Attention is compared to a spotlight, attention selectivity (selective and shared attention) and attention intensity (Alertness, Vigilance) will be compared. Information procession and attention theories are compared (filter model of attention, Broadbent, 1958; Attenuation theory, Treisman 1964; late selection model of selective attention, Deutsch & Deutsch, 1963). At the end an interactive distraction task will be done by the participant (look-point-name). The active control group is comparable in length (+/- 20 minutes), complexity and structure (explanation of the mechanism of attention with the help of graphs, personal involvement through the look-point-name distraction task and a take home message).

Psychopathology: 
Beck Depression Inventory BDI-II (Hautziger, Keller & Kühner, 2009); specific depressive expectations: Depressive expectation scale DES – german version (Kube et al., 2016)

Interpersonal Problems: 
Inventory of interpersonal problems – German Version (IIP-D; Horowitz et al., 2016) 

Personality: 
Big Five Inventory (BFI-10; Rammstedt et al., 2013)

Affect: 
Positive and Negative Affect Schedule PANAS – German Version (Breyer & Bluemke, 2016)

Locus of control (internal vs. external): 
Locus of Control Scale – German Version (IE-4; Kovaleva, Beierlein, Kemper & Rammstedt, 2012)

Well-being: 
Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS; Janke & Glöckner-Rist, 2014) 

Psychological Flexibility: 
German translation of the Acceptance and Action Questionnaire AAQ-II (Fragebogen zur Akzeptanz und Handeln FAH-II;  Hoyer & Gloster, 2013); PsyFlex (in submission, Firsching et al. – Validation Study)

Values: 
List of possible life values (adapted from Harris, 2010) & Triple dominance measure of social value orientation (Van Lange et al., 1997; Murphy & Ackermann, 2014).

Self-formulated items: 
Global expectation of ability to cooperate (scale 0-10, 0=not at all, 10 = extremely) 
Estimated trustworthiness (scale 0-10, 0=not at all, 10 = extremely)
Specific expectation of cooperation in the next trial (probability to cooperate: 0-100%) 
Importance of winning (scale 0-10, 0=not at all, 10 = extremely)
Satisfaction with winning (scale 0-10, 0=not at all, 10 = extremely)
Specific Locus of control referred to the game prisoner`s dilemma (feeling of being able to influence the playing behavior of the other person scale 0-10, 0=not at all, 10 = extremely)
Open question about used strategies in the play of the prisoner`s dilemma (differentiating dominant, cooperative and individual strategy)

Play behavior: 
cooperation vs. defection in the prisoner’s dilemma (coding: “C”, “D”)
ANOVA with repeated measures, within-between interaction is planned to be calculated.

q20.value: Transformations of not normally distributed variables will be done. Especially variables like depressive symptoms, psychopathology, depressive expectations and affect are supposed to be left respectively right skewed due to the participant recruitment of a healthy population.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria.

q22.value: Participants will be excluded from data analysis, if they recognized the illusion about the interactive partner as being fake.

q23.value: In the case of missing data, data could be estimated if it is missing completely at random.

q24.value:
-	Reliability between triple dominance social value orientation measure and quality evaluation of the open questions about used play strategies by participants 
-	Role of expectations and its influence of affect & behavior 
-	Different relations and correlations of the different constructs included in the study 
-	Depression Symptoms and the influence on expectation adaptation 
-	Negative expectations (expecting defection frequently) will be correlated to negative affect; high cognitive immunization of negative social expectations (expecting defection even after positive experience of cooperation of the partner in the prisoner´s dilemma) will be related to a higher negative affect, respectively higher positive expectation adaptation (expecting cooperation faster when partner cooperated) will be followed by higher positive affect

q25.value:
To test the different exploratory analyses and the different hypotheses, different statistical procedures will be chosen to guarantee the optimal statistical evaluation for given data. For the main hypotheses, indicated procedure will be considered, even if secondary statistics will be calculated depending on outcome data. 
The conduct of this study has been approved by the ethics committee of the Philipps-University of Marburg, faculty of Psychology.

Further on, the paper of Sorgi and van´t Wout (2016) on which we orientated our analyses included 31 participants involved in all 3 groups (31 participants per group, without a cross-over design N=92).
registration_responses.q20: Transformations of not normally distributed variables will be done. Especially variables like depressive symptoms, psychopathology, depressive expectations and affect are supposed to be left respectively right skewed due to the participant recruitment of a healthy population.
registration_responses.q21: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria.
registration_responses.q22: Participants will be excluded from data analysis, if they recognized the illusion about the interactive partner as being fake.
registration_responses.q23: In the case of missing data, data could be estimated if it is missing completely at random.
registration_responses.q24:
-	Reliability between triple dominance social value orientation measure and quality evaluation of the open questions about used play strategies by participants 
-	Role of expectations and its influence of affect & behavior 
-	Different relations and correlations of the different constructs included in the study 
-	Depression Symptoms and the influence on expectation adaptation 
-	Negative expectations (expecting defection frequently) will be correlated to negative affect; high cognitive immunization of negative social expectations (expecting defection even after positive experience of cooperation of the partner in the prisoner´s dilemma) will be related to a higher negative affect, respectively higher positive expectation adaptation (expecting cooperation faster when partner cooperated) will be followed by higher positive affect
registration_responses.q25:
To test the different exploratory analyses and the different hypotheses, different statistical procedures will be chosen to guarantee the optimal statistical evaluation for given data. For the main hypotheses, indicated procedure will be considered, even if secondary statistics will be calculated depending on outcome data. 
The conduct of this study has been approved by the ethics committee of the Philipps-University of Marburg, faculty of Psychology.
registration_responses.q8.question:
At first, recruited subjects will be randomized into one of three groups (EFPI, PFFI, active control group). At the beginning, subjects are asked to complete baseline questionnaires (see variables for details). After the baseline assessment, the rules of the iterated prisoner´s dilemma (12 trails) will be explained to the subjects. Afterwards, participants will face a video of another person, thinking it is another participant sitting in another experimental room communicating through video call. This video has been constructed to inject negative expectations towards the person on the video, who is acting very uninterested and distant. The participant will be told to explain the rules of the iterated prisoner´s dilemma to the “other” person. Just afterwards, participants will be asked about their actual affect and their global expectation of cooperation of that other person, who they just met through video call. In a next step, the participant will play the prisoner´s dilemma in repeat believing to play with/against the person they just met on the video conference. To enhance the negative social expectations (the other is not trustworthy and will defect all the time), the algorithm of the prisoner`s dilemma will defect 75%, cooperating in the first, fourth and ninth trial only (CDDDCDDDCDDD; Sorgi & van’t Wout, 2016). The gained money in each trial will be shown in a table summing up the earned points for the participant and the “other” person. Moreover, the participant will be asked how his expectation of play of the opponent person will be (“On a scale from 0 to 100%, how likely do you think the other person will cooperate?”). After the game, participants will again be asked about their actual affective state, their happiness of their earned points and importance of winning, their actual estimate of trustworthiness of the other person, their state of psychological flexibility (PsyFlex, Firsching et al., validation study in submission) and their belief being able to influence the behavior of the other (locus of control).  

Subsequently, participants will receive an intervention, depending on the group they were randomized to. In the EFPI-group participants will be taught about expectations, their influence on their behavior, and their mechanisms of adaptation including immunization. The PFFI-group will consist of interactive work on values, committed action, and defusion with the use of some ACT interventions. Fusion, Evaluation, Avoidance, and reason-giving will be contrasted to accept, choose, and take action. At last, the active control group consists of the explanation of different models of attention and an interactive exercise named “look-point-name” as a distraction task. 

In a third part, social negative expectations will be violated. Again, participants will meet the “other” person per video call and this time the person on the video will be attentive, friendly and interested. Participants shall explain the interventions they received. Further on the affective state will be asked as well as the global trustworthiness and the expectation of the ability to cooperate of the other person.  The prisoner´s dilemma will be played for a second time, the “other” person will now cooperate 75% (DCCCDCCCDCCC) suggesting an expectation violation. Again, the expectation of cooperation or defection of the “other person” will be asked before every trial. At the end, participants are asked to rate their actual affective state, their happiness of their earned points, importance of winning, their actual estimate of trustworthiness of the other person, their state of psychological flexibility and their belief being able to influence the behavior of the other. 

At the end, a follow-up questionnaire will check the validity of the study and the emotional state of the participants to ensure no enduring negative impact of the negative expectation induction. In a last step, participants will be enlightened about the illusion of talking and playing against a real person.
registration_responses.q12.question: Healthy participants will be recruited via flyers distributed and hang up in public places like supermarkets, cinemas or coffee shops, via local groups on social media platforms like Facebook, via SONA (Research Participation System of the Philipps-University of Marburg), as well as through mailing lists of the Philipps-University of Marburg (students and employees). Subjects will receive 8 Euros per hour of participation. Psychology students can receive subject hours they must collect for their bachelor´s degree. The goal is to recruit 100 participants. Healthy participants must be fluent in German, no other exclusion criteria will be applied.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Participants will be randomized into one of three groups: EFPI, FPI and an active control group. The planned content will be described in the following section. 

The expectation focused psychology intervention (EFPI) focuses on making the participant more attentive to expectation violations in order to reduce cognitive immunization and facilitate the integration of positive experiences into positive expectations. At first, a definition of expectations will be discussed with the participant. Dysfunctional (i.e. producing experiential avoidance as a consequence of negative affect) and functional (i.e. planning own behavior to avoid negative consequences) negative expectations will be distinguished, as well as positive and neutral ones. Expectations derive from personality, social surroundings and earlier experiences (Kube et al.,2019). The link between expectations and reactive behavior will be drawn as well as the consequences of it. Different reactions on expectations are explained with focus on immunization. At the end, the whole theoretical background will be elaborated regarding a personal example of the participant (e.g. being afraid of presenting in front of people, being sure to fail in the next exams, expecting my partner to reject me when I say what I want, expecting my partner to reject me, when I am cooperating …). The active and flexible decision of an adaptation of the expectations due to made experiences will be singled out as taking home message. This intervention is hypothesized to make the participant more attentive for expectation violation and thus to a higher adaptation of positive expectations after the positive second interaction. 

In the psychological flexibility focused intervention (PFFI) group, different tasks and metaphors of the acceptance and commitment therapy will be used to promote valued-based behavior and the distance-taking process from cognitions i.e. expectations. Firstly, important values of the participant are singled out with the help of the gravestone metaphor. Values are compared to a compass, giving a direction in life. Secondly, the Bus-driver metaphor will be used to emphasize the influence of daily cognitions due to stress, routine etc. getting the bus off track. This exercise shall include some examples of difficult cognitions of the participant. The image of the monster on the road-side metaphor summarizes the discussion. Fusion, Evaluation, Avoidance and reason-giving is opposed to accept, choose and take action (Wengenroth, 2017). This intervention group should weaken the link between behavior and expectation. The link in the part of positive expectation violation between expectations and actual behavior (i.e. cooperation, defection) will be weaker as in the other groups, respectively in the first prisoner`s dilemma game. Both interventions are comparable in length (+/- 20 minutes), complexity and structure (“psycho-education” or explanation of mechanisms with the help of graphics, personal involvement through the integration and processing of personal examples, take home message).  

The active control group consists of finding a definition of attention with the participant. Attention is compared to a spotlight, attention selectivity (selective and shared attention) and attention intensity (Alertness, Vigilance) will be compared. Information procession and attention theories are compared (filter model of attention, Broadbent, 1958; Attenuation theory, Treisman 1964; late selection model of selective attention, Deutsch & Deutsch, 1963). At the end an interactive distraction task will be done by the participant (look-point-name). The active control group is comparable in length (+/- 20 minutes), complexity and structure (explanation of the mechanism of attention with the help of graphs, personal involvement through the look-point-name distraction task and a take home message).
registration_responses.q17.question:
Psychopathology: 
Beck Depression Inventory BDI-II (Hautziger, Keller & Kühner, 2009); specific depressive expectations: Depressive expectation scale DES – german version (Kube et al., 2016)

Interpersonal Problems: 
Inventory of interpersonal problems – German Version (IIP-D; Horowitz et al., 2016) 

Personality: 
Big Five Inventory (BFI-10; Rammstedt et al., 2013)

Affect: 
Positive and Negative Affect Schedule PANAS – German Version (Breyer & Bluemke, 2016)

Locus of control (internal vs. external): 
Locus of Control Scale – German Version (IE-4; Kovaleva, Beierlein, Kemper & Rammstedt, 2012)

Well-being: 
Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS; Janke & Glöckner-Rist, 2014) 

Psychological Flexibility: 
German translation of the Acceptance and Action Questionnaire AAQ-II (Fragebogen zur Akzeptanz und Handeln FAH-II;  Hoyer & Gloster, 2013); PsyFlex (in submission, Firsching et al. – Validation Study)

Values: 
List of possible life values (adapted from Harris, 2010) & Triple dominance measure of social value orientation (Van Lange et al., 1997; Murphy & Ackermann, 2014).

Self-formulated items: 
Global expectation of ability to cooperate (scale 0-10, 0=not at all, 10 = extremely) 
Estimated trustworthiness (scale 0-10, 0=not at all, 10 = extremely)
Specific expectation of cooperation in the next trial (probability to cooperate: 0-100%) 
Importance of winning (scale 0-10, 0=not at all, 10 = extremely)
Satisfaction with winning (scale 0-10, 0=not at all, 10 = extremely)
Specific Locus of control referred to the game prisoner`s dilemma (feeling of being able to influence the playing behavior of the other person scale 0-10, 0=not at all, 10 = extremely)
Open question about used strategies in the play of the prisoner`s dilemma (differentiating dominant, cooperative and individual strategy)

Play behavior: 
cooperation vs. defection in the prisoner’s dilemma (coding: “C”, “D”)

attributes.title: Peer Influence as a Mediator between Perceived Masculinity & Alcohol Use

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Peer Influence as a Mediator between Perceived Masculinity & Alcohol Use

other.value:
Other group members include: Jessica Cecilia Bose (National University of Singapore) e0035467@u.nus.edu &
Navasharsheaswari Nalusamy (National University of Singapore) e0203302@u.nus.edu

sample.value: Each group member will gather 10 responses each, so the sample size will total up to 70.

analyses.value: We will use structural equation modeling, which combines factor analysis and multiple regression analysis to analyse relationships between the variables measured in the survey.

outliers.value: We will check for the fit of the structural models, so even in the event there are indeed outliers, if the fit is good the outliers will not cause significant difference to our data.

dependent.value:
DV: Alcohol use. 
Alcohol use is measured using a survey in which participants will be requires to report the frequency they consume “beer, wine coolers or hard cider”. This is on a 1-5 scale, with (1) being never to a few times per year, a few times per month, once or twice a week, and three or more times per week as (5). 

Mediator: Peer pressure and conformity is measured using Santor, Messervey and Kusukamar’s (2000) measure of peer pressure which includes a peer pressure subscale and general (adult) conformity.
Peer pressure refers to the social pressure by peers to conform to norms, and conformity can refer to pressure by parents and other adults to behave in a specific manner.

conditions.value: Participants are not assigned to any conditions since this is a correlational study. Participants will instead complete surveys regarding conformity to masculine norms, peer pressure and general conformity, and alcohol use.

hypothesis.value:
Main question: How does peer influence mediate the relationship between masculine norms and alcohol use among adolescent boys and girls? 
We hypothesise that both boys and girls who adhere to masculine norms will seek out certain types of peers and be at heightened risk of engaging in risky behaviour like alcohol use.
