attributes.title: A digital approach to workplace mental health: A randomized controlled trial examining the effectiveness of a smartphone-based personalised intervention

q1.value: A digital approach to workplace mental health: A randomized controlled trial examining the effectiveness of a smartphone-based personalised intervention

q2.value: Megan Chor Kwan Lam, Sisi LI, Charlie Lau , Celeb Chiu, Meanne Chan

q3.value: Existing research establishes that working adults are particularly vulnerable to stress and other mental health problems. Local evidence suggests that the majority of people who suffered from mental disorder did not seek help because of the stigma attached to seeking mental health services. Previous studies have demonstrated the potential of online intervention in alleviating psychological distress and acting as an alternative to face-to-face therapy. To harness the power of technology in promoting mental health, this study features a personalised intervention that can be deployed in real-time.

q4.value:
It is expected that this platform would be effective in reducing psychological distress, as indexed by within-group (pre-intervention and post-intervention) and between-group (personalised intervention, non-personalised intervention, and waitlist group)  DASS-21 scores. 
Specifically, it is hypothesised that a) the DASS-21 score will decrease significantly for the two intervention groups but not for the waitlist group; b) further, the personalised intervention group will show a greater decrease in DASS-21 score compared with the non-personalised intervention group. And additionally at daily level, c) the DASS-21 scores will decrease significantly along time for the two intervention groups but not for the waitlist group; d) within each intervention group, participants who practice more intervention sessions will show a larger decrease in DASS-21 scores; e) participants who have larger pre-intervention emotion variability will show a larger decrease in DASS-21 scores.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Between subject design with repeated measures will be adopted. Participants will be randomised into three conditions, namely the personalised intervention group, the non-personalised intervention group, or the waitlist control group. Ecological momentary intervention (EMI) coupled with ecological momentary assessment (EMA) will be carried out for 4 weeks.

q9.value:
Simple randomisation is adopted.  

A randomisation algorithm will be inserted during the application registration logic where it will tag a user as one of the three types (a, b, or c). The algorithm will return a random value on a range between 0-1 with an equally weighted bracket defined for each type. The generated random value will fall into either one of the defined brackets and the associated user will be tagged and assigned the type. Upon logging into the app, the user either is directed into the personalised intervention App (a, namely the personalised intervention condition), the non-personalised App (b, namely the non-personalised intervention condition), or the waiting screen for the app (c, namely the waitlist group).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
400 participants will be recruited from a local company for a 4-week online intervention programme. Participants will complete DASS-21 among other baseline measures before the EMI/A session, and receive instruction regarding how to install/use the smartphone-based intervention App. The EMI/A session is immediately available for data input after onboarding, in which participants will record their daily mood journals, practise EMI sessions, and respond to DASS-21 measure. 

As our study involves anonymous users from a local company, no information is available about participants' clinical history and diagnosis. However, two employees who were previously diagnosed with mental disorders will be excluded. 
Relatedly, if a user reports an extreme level of depression, anxiety, and/or stress on the App in the middle of data collection, he or she will be immediately promoted to a credited hotline due to safety protocols.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 297 participants (99 participants/group * 3 groups), and we aim at recruiting around 400 participants assuming the attrition rate as 25% given the intensiveness of our data collection.

q14.value:
A power analysis was conducted following Chan (2003), to determine the minimum number of participants required for the randomised controlled trials design. Assuming medium standardised effect size (0.4), with an alpha level of 0.05, a minimum of 99 participants per group is needed to achieve a power of 0.80 to detect the hypothesised effects.
For simplicity, priori power analysis was conducted only for the key analyses, namely the repeated measures ANOVA examining the effectiveness of the smartphone based online intervention. EMI/A usually has high power given its intensive sampling approach, hence is not concerned here.

question.value: We will manipulate clinical trial conditions (personalised intervention group, non-personalised intervention group, and waitlist control group).

The primary outcome will be the effectiveness of the online platform in reducing psychological distress, as indexed by within-group (pre-intervention and post-intervention) and between-group (intervention and wait-list group)  DASS-21 scores. 
In addition to the effectiveness of the online platform, we will also include measures of personality, individuals' orientations towards loneliness, self-esteem, social support, socio-economic status and psychological need satisfaction. 
Demographic information will be gathered before the study onboards, namely age, gender, educational level, marital status and household income.

Multiple data analysis methods will be adopted to examine our hypotheses and to cross-validate the effectiveness of our smartphone-based intervention App. 
1. To examine the effectiveness of our smartphone intervention App (Hypothesis a and b), DASS-21 scores will be submitted to repeated measures ANOVA (3 groups (between: personalised intervention/non-personalised intervention/waitlist groups) * 2 times (within: pre/post)). Planned contrasts will be conducted to compare the effects between the non-personalised intervention and the waitlist control groups, probing the effectiveness of the online intervention methods adopted; and between the personalised and the non-personalised intervention groups, probing the additional effectiveness of the personalised feature of the smartphone based App.
2. To model the mental health trajectories (Hypothesis c), multilevel modeling will be adopted such that EMA measures will be regressed on time, condition, and the interaction between time and condition, controlling for the baseline mental health conditions.
3. EMA measures will be regressed on time, the number of intervention sessions practiced, and pre-intervention emotion variability (Hypothesis d and e), controlling for the baseline mental health conditions.

q20.value: For multilevel modeling analyses, time-varying predictor(s) will be person-mean centered such that the effects modelled will represent the variation about a given participant's own average level.

q21.value: For primary analysis, p-value is set to 0.05. For planned contrasts, Bonferroni correction will be adopted.

q22.value:
As stated in the sampling plan, if a person reports extreme level of depression, anxiety, and/or stress on the App in the middle of data collection, the person will be immediately promoted a credited hotline due to safety protocols, and the responses will be excluded from data analyses accordingly.
Awareness check will not be used.

q23.value: As ecological momentary assessment will be employed, participants who contribute to fewer than 5 daily signals will be excluded from data analysis for reliability concern. For participants retained, null response on any day or any item of a given day will be treated as missing data and thus excluded from data analyses.

q24.value:
Exploratory analyses will be conducted to test whether the EMI affects other psychological dimensions, e.g., psychological need satisfaction, level of loneliness, and self-esteem. 
Models specified in the primary analysis sessions will control for baseline characteristics (e.g.,   social support and personality for exploratory purposes.
As demographic information might be related with smartphone usage or App preference, we will look for relationships among demographic variables (e.g., age, gender, SES, and marital status), the number of practiced EMI sessions, and DASS-21 post- scores.

q25.value:
Reference
Chan, Y. H. (2003). Randomised controlled trials (RCTs)-sample size: the magic number?. Singapore medical journal, 44(4), 172-174.

attributes.title: Practice-based Implementation and Innovation SysteM (PRIISM): Back Pain Implementation Feasibility Study
attributes.description: ‘PRIISM Back Pain’ is a health care quality improvement project aiming to increase consistency in the delivery of evidence-based care to patients with low back pain (LBP) by physiotherapists.

attributes.title: Self-Persuasion Though Mode of Story Transmission

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Lay beliefs regarding persuasion modality: We examine whether people think that others will be more self-persuaded by speaking or writing a persuasive story.

other.value: We may measure participants' judgments of others' self-transportation (adapted from Appel, Richter, Gnambs, and Green 2015).

analyses.value: A mixed ANOVA, with the speak versus write measurements as within subject factors, and the topic replicate as between subject factors.

outliers.value: Participants who fail an attention check question will be removed.

dependent.value:
We will ask participants to predict the results of a study. We will ask them to estimate others' behavior when people are asked to speak a persuasive story about a topic (drinking alcohol or using sunscreen) or write a story. 

"For people who speak their story, what is the likelihood that they will use sunscreen the next time they spend an extended amount of time outside with exposed skin / drink alcohol in a healthy manner the next time they consume alcohol?" (The same question will be repeated for those who write the story).

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two conditions: an alcohol context or a sunscreen use context.

registration_responses.name: Lay beliefs regarding persuasion modality: We examine whether people think that others will be more self-persuaded by speaking or writing a persuasive story.
registration_responses.other: We may measure participants' judgments of others' self-transportation (adapted from Appel, Richter, Gnambs, and Green 2015).
registration_responses.analyses: A mixed ANOVA, with the speak versus write measurements as within subject factors, and the topic replicate as between subject factors.
registration_responses.outliers: Participants who fail an attention check question will be removed.

attributes.title: SMS for Better Governance: Pre-Analysis Plan

q1.value: SMS for Better Governance: Pre-Analysis Plan

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: We describe our plan for assessing the impact of UBridge---an innovative SMS service allowing direct communication between citizens and local government officials---on service delivery outcomes. The program was launched in August 2014 and the last program activities were held in early 2016 in Arua district in northern Uganda. We examine the effect of the program on three domains: local government monitoring of service providers, service provider effort, and service provider inputs. Service sectors include health, education, and water. This plan has been written after the data were collected, but before the authors had access to data that could be used to analyze treatment effects.

q16.value: We hypothesize that access to an innovative SMS-platform will increase service delivery outcomes for treatment villages in northern Uganda, compared to control villages that had no access to the platform. We test this hypothesis on three sectors---health, education and water---and on three families of outcomes in each sector: monitoring, facility effort and inputs. We further hypothesize that the treatment should have the stronger effect on monitoring and the weakest effect on inputs. As for heterogeneous effects, we hypothesize that effects will be larger for (a) ethnically homogenous villages, and (b) villages located far from the district capital.

q17.value: We plan creating indices for families of outcomes in the three service delivery sectors (monitoring, effort and inputs), whereby the variables that make up the index have been explicitly named in the PAP. We then plan to regress the index (and their constituent variables) using OLS, clustering standard errors at the health center catchment area (the study's unit of randomization). Following Lin (2013), we also plan reporting regressions that include covariates adjustment, whereby the covariates have also been pre-specified in the PAP.

q19.value: 122 treatment villages and 102 control villages clustered in 48 health center catchment areas (24 health center cluster were randomly assigned to treatment and 24 to control).

q24.value: The project has been approved by the Uganda National Council for Science and Technology (Project \# SS 3266) and the Office of the President in Uganda.
